MUSIC: OPENING THEME
SCENE 1: INT. SPACEPORT — CUSTOMS
(FX: HEATHROW AIRPORT AFTER 400 YEARS. SOME EMERGENCY LIGHTING
FIZZES. CAVERNOUS ROOM. HYDRAULIC WHEEZE AS DOOR OPENS OFF AND NAYSMITH WALKS IN, WITH PRETTY, THROUGH EXPECTANT CROWD)
(EXCITED, AWAITING CEREMONY) Here she comes!/ Good luck, Naysmith!/
Cleared landings, little Naysmith!/
Fancy you, all grown up!
(AS SHE WALKS) Thank you! Thank you! (ASIDE, TO PRETTY) You really won’t tell me what’s going to happen?
(WALKING) Can’t. Sorry.
Pretty, you’re supposed to tell your girlfriend everything. And usually I can’t stop you.
Every initiation task is different. (STOPS) Stand here.
(WALKING UP BEHIND) I do hope you’re not telling her anything, Pretty.
No, Mum, I was just saying. You make your task with Elder Bones.
Hello, Mrs Swanson.
Beauty, please. I keep saying. Mrs Swanson is so formal.
(CONTINUING HIS TRAIN OF THOUGHT) And the task is a binding contract.
(A MILD CURSE, LIKE ‘SAINTS ALIVE!’) Sweet luggage! When did you go over to Business? (RE THE CURSE) Sorry, Mrs Sw-. (CORRECTING HERSELF) Sorry, Beauty.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 3
We’1ll not talk about that Business lot today. We’re here to celebrate you, Economy’s newest initiate. Are you excited?
(YES) Nervous, too.
You'll be fine.
FX: DOOR CREAKS OPEN AHEAD
He’s here! Elder Bones!
AS ELDER BONES STRIDES TOWARDS THEM:
(HUSHED) It’s time. How do I look?
(HUSHED) Terrified.
(HUSHED) Thanks. What do I see in you again?
(HUSHED) It’s a mystery.
(STOPPING, CLEARING HIS THROAT, THEN: LOUDLY) We begin.
(BY ROTE) We welcome Elder Bones.
Your welcome is received. Those of you with candles, step closer so that all might see. Give a light to our young initiate. (TO NAYSMITH) What is your name?
I am Naysmith, sir. I stand ready to face [the tasks that await me ]
Not quite yet, my dear. But I admire your eagerness.
SNICKER
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 4

(TO ALL) Now, now. This is a big day for little Naysmith. And this is a big place for her to choose her future. This is a most special room. Our ancestors knew this, even when all this was a working spaceport. (DARKLY) Before the coming of the Wailer. (BACK TO NORMAL) Our ancestors knew the importance of tradition. They named this place after those traditions. They called it... “Customs”. Initiate?
Sir.
You have been taught the Customs of Economy?
Sir. I travel light, I have learned to live on little liquids.
As each of you reaches your twentieth year, so you make your decision. It’s been some time since I was twenty —
PAUSES FOR — AND GETS — THE POLITE LAUGH HE’S EXPECTING

And in all my time here, I have seen much, I have guided many generations. But this is the day I most look forward to. A new soul leaves childhood and takes their place in our community — if they are able, if they are ready. (PROMPTING) Now, Naysmith.
Elder Bones, sir, I stand ready to face the task that awaits me.
Friends, schoolmates and family of Naysmith, do you say she is ready?
We do, Elder Bones.

(TO NAYSMITH) Come forward, Naysmith. Bring your candle. Hold it high. Regard the paths behind me and the ancient writings above them. Two paths. Two choices. Decide now whether you are truly brave and wish to serve your people, or if you will forever be a passenger. Have you decided?
I have, Elder Bones. I choose to serve my community. I have Something to Declare.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL)
CROWD APPLAUDS. PRETTY WHISTLES
(URGING, SOTTO VOCE) Go on, Naysmith!
(SOTTO) Don’t hang around!
(TO ELDER BONES) Do I go now, Elder Bones?
Come with me, we’ll walk the path together.
EXIT NAYSMITH AND ELDER BONES
CHEER THEM OFF
FADE
Page 5
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 2: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: IN FLIGHT
Mel, not five minutes ago, you told me you wished we could go on racketing about the galaxy forever. Now you want to stop.
Not stop, no, just take in the view. All I’m saying is it would be nice to look out every now and then. Travelling through all of time and space and we haven’t even got a window.
(POINTING) And what exactly would you call that?
(SIGHS) A scanner screen, Doctor.
Well, there you are.
And it’s shut. My gran put her TV set in a cupboard, too. We missed Andrew and Fergie’s wedding because she lost the key.
Then let’s find you something to look out at. (FX: ACTIVATING SCANNER) Maybe something that lasts.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 3: INT. CORRIDOR 1
(FX: CORRIDOR 1 IS SMALL, QUIET. CREAKING METAL WALLS, MORE
VENTS. NAYSMITH AND ELDER BONES WALK TO A STOP)
(SLIGHTLY OUT OF BREATH) This is far enough. I’m not as young as I was and we’re well clear of Customs now. Blow out your candle, let your eyes adjust.
(BLOWS OUT CANDLE) Sir. Will my task help us all leave the spaceport?
We have many more steps before that glorious day.
They say there’s a whole world outside.
Naysmith, let me ‘level with you’. The water situation is much worse than is generally known. We will soon have no choice but to take control of the hydroponics garden, and the water mills too.
But Business occupy the gardens.
They do. And Business have the Wailer.
I don’t know what I can do. Sir.

You’re young and fast and agile. Scout the Business garden, find where they are strongest and report back to me. We have such little time left, you must find us the way so that we can prepare to fight the Business.
Yes, sir.
Look now, can you see along the walls there? That faint glow.
Candles? No, something else.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 8
Emergency strip lights will show you the way. But if Business appears, get out of there, fast. And Naysmith?
Sir?
If you’re caught, remember that the nearest way out may be behind you.
Sir.
SHE WALKS OUT. FADE
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 4: INT. HYDROPONICS GARDEN
(FX: SURGING WATERMILL, OFF. ‘STORM’ RUMBLES: THE SPACEPORT IS
BY A FORCEFIELD — AND WE’LL LEARN THAT THE ‘STORM’
IS THE SOUND OF FORCEFIELD UNDER FIRE. SOUNDS OF ALARM FROM A
BUSINESS PEOPLE, OFF)
A CURSE) Boarding hell! Not another storm, not now. (CALLING
You two! Leave your duties. I’1ll guard the water mills — you get to the lounges, stay with the women and children.
(HURRYING UP) Rogers! Get everybody back to the business lounge.
Already done it, ma’am. What’s happening? The soil farm buckled right in front of me. Burst one of the mills.
It’s not just the soil farm. Everything’s straining — the whole garden. The whole spaceport, I shouldn’t be surprised. As if the storm is finally going to get through. Are you armed?
How do we fight a storm with a gun?
Read the memos, Rogers. Director says Economy’s having another initiation. Last thing we need. Is your gun charged?
(CHECKING IT — A LITTLE HUM OF POWER) Enough. Four greens. We needed the trickle charge plates to power up the repair irons, I’m afraid.
It’1ll do. (CHECKS HERS — A SIMILAR HUM) I’ve got five greens on mine. Now, circle the garden — make sure our people are safe. But be careful.
I won’t go near the vents, ma’am, I can tell you that.
Circle quickly, let’s get the gardens secured and join the others. No Economy kid is going take what’s ours.
(BY ROTE) We share all we have.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 10
(BY ROTE) But we hold it all for Business.
GALPAN/ROGERS: (TOGETHER, BY ROTE) We are Shareholders.
Circuit the garden. I’1l go [this way]
FX: ‘STORM’ GETS LOUDER; A SOUND OF METAL SHEARING
(SOTTO, ALARMED) Ma’am! Get down!
(SOTTO) Did you see something?
(SOTTO) By the far vent, maybe.
(SOTTO) ‘Maybe’?
(SOTTO, BITTERLY) Well I can’t see properly, can I? I keep telling them: if we could just divert power to lights, we could see what’s going on.
(SOTTO) Business has survived the darkness for centuries. We don’t need the light. Call them.
(CALLING AHEAD) You there. Business or pleasure?
BEAT
(STANDING UP) False alarm, Rogers. There’s nobody there.
Sorry, ma’am. Storm must be making me jumpy.
(FX: STORM CRACKS CEILING — METAL SHARDS FALL ON HIDING NAYSMITH)
YELPS, OFF
There is someone! Over by the vents! Look!
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 11
An Economy kid! (ALOUD) Stay where you are!
OFF) Oh, sweet luggage. (SHE RUNS
You! Stop! (FX: LASER BLAST) (TO ROGERS) Come on! She’s getting away! (SHE & ROGERS RUN AFTER NAYSMITH)
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 5: INT. CUSTOMS
FX: STORM SOUNDS, SLIGHTLY WEAKER
(PANICKED) Never been this bad. Where is Elder Bones?
(TO ALL) Okay, everybody! The storm’s bad, I know, but it’s fading now.
(TO ALL) Just stay calm until Elder Bones is back.
(TO ALL) Let’s all sit down and assume Crash Positions!
FX: A FINAL CRASH OF THUNDER
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 13
SCENE 6: INT. CORRIDOR 2
(FX: THINK OF THOSE AIRPORT CORRIDORS LEADING TO TERMINALS: WIDE, LONG, WITH BRANCHES OFF AND LOTS OF DISPLAY CABINETS AND
MACHINES. NAYSMITH RUNS THROUGH, DODGING AROUND OBSTACLES. WE ARE WITH NAYSMITH. )
(RUNNING BEHIND, WITH ROGERS. OFF: ) There she is! By the machines!
OFF) I see her! (FX: FIRES...
FX: ONE COKE MACHINE SHATTERS RIGHT BESIDE NAYSMITH
YELPS, RUNS ON PAST US
(RUNS UP TO US, WITH GALPAN. PANTING.) Nearly got her there.
(PANTING) Yeah, and what’s the Director going to say when he finds you’ve shot up all the artefacts?
Cost of doing business, ma’am. Besides, if he wants us to admire his precious “Vending” artefacts, let him switch on some lights so we can see them.
Come on. She must be heading [towards —]
(FX: DISTANTLY, FROM ARRIVALS — THE ROOM BEYOND — THE TARDIS MATERIALISING)
What’s that noise? The artefacts? (FEAR) It’s not.. The Wailer, ala 3s
Can’t be, it came from Arrivals.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 7: INT. ARRIVALS
(FX: CAVERNOUS BUT EMPTY SPACE. TARDIS MATERIALISATION ENDS,
OPENS)
(STEPPING OUT) .. I can’t believe it. I really thought they were as strong as Charles and Di.
(EMERGING) Yes, well. (STEPS OUT) Oh. It’s very dark here, don’t you think?
FX: SHUTS THE TARDIS DOOR
Like a submarine. Red lights. Echoey, too.
(CALLING TO TEST THE ECHO) Hello?
(FX: THE WHUMP-WHUMP-WHUMP OF LIGHTS SWITCHING ON. STADIUM LIGHTS, HUGE — SO BRIGHT THEY’RE BLINDING. )
(PAINED) Those lights!
Dazzling. Arc lights, and rather a lot of them.
(FX: LIGHTS CONTINUE TO WHOMP ON, GETTING FURTHER AWAY FROM THEM. THE HUGE, HUGE ROOM IS COMING ALIVE)
Why do I feel like I should be raising my hands?
Welcome to Tantane Spaceport. There is one arrival.
Welcome to Tantane Spaceport. Twinned with the Dewplayser Cluster, proud sponsor of the Tantane Cathedral Games.
Welcome to Tantane Spaceport.
Three guesses where we are.
The red zone is for oxygen-breathers. The white zone is for zero gravity methane-based lifeforms.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 15
Let’s hope we’re in the red zone, then.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 8: INT. CORRIDOR 2
(PROCEEDING ALONG CORRIDOR) Who’d dare enter Arrivals?
(PROCEEDING ALONG CORRIDOR) We’1ll find out soon. At least the storm’s blown over —
FX: WHUMP-WHOMP — ARC LIGHTS KICKING ON
Sweet credit, the lights are coming on!
I don’t believe it —
You know what this means, ma’am —
(SUDDENLY) There, by the cola-vend!
(SLIGHTLY OFF, AMAZED) The lights! It’s summer...!
The Economy kid!
. Summer has come back!
Fire!
FX: NAYSMITH RUNS AS ROGERS FIRES
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 9: INT. ARRIVALS
Welcome to Tantane Spaceport. We apologise for the delay to your journey.
This should be one of the busiest spaceports in the galaxy, yet it seems completely deserted.
Not completely. Someone turned on the lights for us.
That’s a little unexpected, I’1l admit. I’m not usually welcomed.
Yes, I’ve learnt that.
People warm to me eventually. Most of the time.
Of course they do, Doctor. I suppose the lights could have come on automatically. Shall we take a look around?
Seems rude not to now. This looks like Arrivals. If this Spaceport is still operational, there must be people around somewhere.
FX: OFF, A SLIDING DOOR OPENS. NAYSMITH RUNS IN
There, for instance. Hello!
(STARTLED) Oh! Who are you?
FX: THE SLIDING DOOR CLOSES BEHIND HER WITH A SLICE
Wait! The wall. A hole appeared in the wall! And it’s gone
again. How did it go?
(COMING FORWARD) I’m Mel, and this is the Doctor.
Stay back, I haven’t done anything.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 18
Nor have we.
Did... did you bring the summer?
I have been known to light up a room.
(TO NAYSMITH) Usually with his coat of many colours.
(STEPPING FORWARD TO LOOK) Yes, we make our clothes in the dark, too.
Charming.
FX: THE DOOR OPENS BEHIND
(TO DOCTOR AND MEL) The wall is opening again. Quickly! Hide!
I don’t hide. From whom should I hide?
(AT DOOR) Us. My name is Galpan and this is Rogers. Are you Business or Economy?
Madam, I am always first class.
He means ‘hello’! I’m Mel, this is —
First? (DISTASTE) She’s in leisurewear!
Dissolve them, Rogers.
What? No —
(FX: SUDDENLY, A METAL WALL SLIDES ACROSS, CUTTING OFF ROGERS AND GALPAN. IT SOUNDS DIFFERENT FROM THE DOOR. )
Oh! I thought we’d had it for a moment!
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 19
The walls, they’re breathing! One inhales and the other exhales.
(TO NAYSMITH) It’s just a sliding door. This place must be full of them.
(TAPPING WALL) No, it wasn’t a door cut us off from our nasty new friends — whoever they were...
They’re Business. They like to make their killings look like accidents — but make no mistake, it’s merger.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 10: INT. CORRIDOR 2
FX: LASER FIRING AT WALL
Enough! (THE LASERS STOP) It’s pointless, Rogers. It’s not even scratching the surface. We may as well save the charge.

You realise what this means, don’t you, ma’am? All the lights, the sounds, everything is back. We’ve got power again! No ekeing out what we can pull from the garden systems — we can use the recharging plates as much as we like! Get all the guns fully powered.
FX: FIRES AGAIN, LAUGHING
Quit it! (HE STOPS) This has happened before and it doesn’t last.
Not in my lifetime, ma’am — nor, I’1l warrant, in yours. Doesn’t it make you feel alive?
My Granddad called it ‘Summer’. He never knew why the summer came back, he never knew why it left again. But he was really clear that it doesn’t last.
Can’t we stop it going? This is like being outside the spaceport, I don’t want to go back to the darkness.
He said one other thing about Summer: it only happens when strangers arrive.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 21
SCENE 11: INT. ARRIVALS
(EXAMINING THE WALL) It’s not door, nor a shutter. It’s like the whole wall shut. But why, I wonder?
To protect us?
They say the walls breathe
Just ‘Doctor’, thanks. (FX
What’s your name?
Naysmith. I’m an Initiate.
in summer, Elder Doctor.
: TAPS WALL AGAIN)

(NOT INTERESTED) How interesting. (THINKING ALOUD) You know, I would have sworn this was a supporting structural wall. Which makes the fact that it moved a very singular one. But perhaps I’ve mis-remembered my spaceport design.
Surely not.
FX: ANOTHER WALL MOVING, OFF
There goes another wall. More and more singular.
(TO NAYSMITH) Naysmith: who were those men?
I said. They’re Business. first class?
(PROUD) I’m Economy. Doctor, what is
Young lady, it means I am in a class all of my own.
Can’t argue with that.
FX: ANOTHER WALL MOVES
There goes another one.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 22
It’s not natural.
It’s fascinating. Like an art installation. As if the walls were trying out new structures. New perspectives. This whole room has changed shape while we’ve been standing here.
And something’s gone missing.
Missing?
There was a little control panel over there, like an information booth. It’s now on the other side of that wall.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 12: INT. CORRIDOR 2
What is it, ma’am?
It’s what the Director calls a ‘control panel’. You touch the screen like this, and —
FX: SHE TOUCHES AND A TONE SOUNDS, RESPONDING
(WORRY) What’s that light? And why’s it flashing?
Relax, Rogers. Tap your finger on it. Go on.
If you’re sure it’s safe, ma’am.
(FX: HE TAPS THE ICON, A BLEEP OF RECOGNITION. A VOICE
Welcome to Tantane Information System. Press for Restaurants, Tourist Guide or Business.
Business? That’s us!
Tap it.
‘Business’...
FX: ROGERS DOES SO; A BLEEP OF RECOGNITION
Business. Press for email services, conference calls, hotel
bookings [shuttle rental, executive services...]
FX: CROSSFADE TO:
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 13: INT. CUSTOMS
FX: ‘STORM’ HAS CALMED. THE LIGHTS HAVE SWITCHED ON HERE TOO
HALF-DELIGHTED, HALF-SCARED, ALL-AMAZED
They’re on at the back too!
They’re everywhere!
I’ve never seen Summer!
Pretty. Come here.
(APPROACHING) Mother?
Pretty Swanson! Oh, my son, you look so pale — so pale and yet so handsome in the light.
Welcome to Tantane Spaceport. There is one arrival.
Listen to that, Mum: one arrival! Strangers have come and they’ve brought the summer. Look around you. Lights, power, everything. We can use it!
Strangers, yes. Outsiders. I never believed it could be true — people... outside!
Worry about the insiders. Business will use the summer too.
They say that last time it came, they let the Wailer loose.
That’s just Economy talk. They wouldn’t do that.
Wouldn’t they...?
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 14: INT. ARRIVALS
FX: A WALL IS MOVING
Watch yourself, Mel. The walls are off again.
FX: WALL GRINDS INTO POSITION
(DODGING IT) Oh! — That was close. You don’t think the walls are trying to surround us, do you?
If you’re not Business or Economy, how did you get here?
This is Arrivals. Don’t you have visitors every day?
Not like you, no. Arrivals is where we come from, where we are born.
A maternity ward?
I’m not going to ask what Departures is.
Welcome to Tantane Spaceport. We apologise for the delay to your onward journey. Quarantine measures will soon be completed.
Quarantine? Maybe that’s what the sliding walls are about?
Please, who is saying all these things and why won’t they stop?
FX: DOOR SWISHES OPEN, OFF
Doctor, there’s a door in this latest wall!
Our Business acquaintances again. Quickly, [hide —]
No! It’s all right: it’s Elder Bones! (LOUD) Over here, sir.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 26
(APPROACHING) Little Naysmith! And who have we here? Are these... arrivals?
FX: DOOR SLICES SHUT
Hello! I’m Mel, this is the Doctor.
It is their ritual, Elder Bones. She says “Hello, I’m Mel, this is the Doctor,” and he ignores everyone.
(TO DOCTOR) Got you sized up, hasn’t she?
Mel. Doctor.
(TO MEL, URGENTLY) You’re supposed to bow your head.
Oh, sorry. Yes.
(TO MEL) Your welcome is received, Mel.
(HISSED) Now you, Doctor-!
I bow to no man, Mel. At least, not until I know enough to respect him. (TO ELDER BONES) Tell me, ‘Elder Bones’ — is it
you that’s moving these walls?
Not I, Doctor. The spaceport itself.
The spaceport-—?
Welcome to Tantane Spaceport.
It does like to welcome us, doesn’t it?
We apologise for the delay in disabling your ship.
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 27
What?
Anti-matter containment engines have been neutralised. Anti- gravity launch systems reversed.
Doctor, does that mean us?
Hardly. The TARDIS doesn’t need anti-matter.
Physical restraining measures continue.
Now what are they, I wonder?
Alas, the ways of the spaceport are a mystery to me.
Physical restraint will be completed shortly. Thank you for your patience.
I really think that means us. Could the walls be closing in to suffocate us?

This is a spaceport. A sealed environment. If that’s what it wanted, it could shut down the atmosphere. No, I think our arrival has tripped some other process. As to what it is, I couldn’t hazard a guess.
FX: ANOTHER WALL MOVES SOMEWHERE
But it must be for a reason. Must be.
(LOOKING) Yes, and I’ve just realised what it is!
Oh? Really?
Look over there. The TARDIS has gone!
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 15: INT. CORRIDOR 2
FX: PANEL TONE
Look at this, Rogers! I think this is a map and these two small blue dots represent us, here at this panel.
Then I’1l bet you an audit I know what this button does...
LOTS OF LITTLE BLEEPS
(SARCASTIC) Brilliant, Rogers, quite brilliant. Now there are hundreds of blue dots!
Don’t you see? It’s everybody. If this is us, then that’s got to be hydroponics and the business lounge. That’s where most of the blue dots are, because that’s where most of our people are.
You’re right. And so those... (SHE INDICATES TWO BLOBS ON THE MAP) will be the strangers. Four dots. I thought there might be more of them.
Ma’am. There: what’s that?
Economy, I shouldn’t wonder. All clustered together in a ball of cheap misery.
I don’t think so. That’s not a bunch of individual dots — that’s just one dot. One very big dot.
The Wailer.
But it’s always been trapped at the Control Tower. What’s it doing sitting there?
It’s not sitting, Rogers. It’s moving.
And so are Economy. Now where are they going to?
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 29
It won’t be anywhere we like. Typical. Every chance they get, they take and take. No pitch, no buyout. They’re just like — like (SPITS) franchises.
If they keep going that way, they’1ll reach the Business Lounge.
Boarding hell. (BEAT) Forget the strangers, we’ve got a job to do. Come on!
(FX: THEY LEAVE. WALL BEGINS TO TURN, ROTATING CONTROL PANEL INTO...)
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 16: INT. ARRIVALS
This is an outrage. (CALLING) Spaceport! Spaceport! I demand you return my vessel to me at once!
FX: WALL COMPLETES ROTATION, DISCLOSING CONTROL PANEL
Doctor, look! That information booth’s come back!
An attempt to communicate, perhaps? (STEPPING TOWARDS IT; THE
FOLLOW) Right, then...
You understand the control panels, Doctor?
In principle, certainly. Now, then... (FX: PANEL TONE)
Welcome to Tantane Information System. Press for Restaurants, Tourist Guide or Business.
(ALARM) Business!
No good to us. (THINKS) Let’s try this little envelope: ‘Sent Messages’. (FX: PANEL TONE)
Is there anything I can do?
Watch and learn. (FX: PANEL BLEEP) A-ha! ‘Retrieve messages’. (A BLEEP) Ooh, a video attachment! And... ‘Play video’.
(FX: PANEL TONE — THEN, OVER SCREEN, WITH SCREAMS AND CRIES OF
PASSENGERS IN B/G:)
(TERRIFIED, OVER SCREEN) It’s here. The Wailer is here!
Oh, my lights.
(TERRIFIED, OVER SCREEN) If you receive this message, don’t let Earth send help! You can’t land here, you mustn’t land [here] — NO!!!
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 31
(FX: START OF WAILER SCREECH [SEE LATER] — CUT OFF BY FUZZ OF STATIC. MESSAGE CUTS OUT)
That’s it. The last message sent from this booth. When was that, I wonder...?
Horrible. Just before the end, I saw a flash of something grey. Something with teeth. Was that...?
(FEARFUL) The Wailer.
It lives in the Tower, now. It guards Control.
Control? You mean the spaceport’s Control Tower?
When the spaceport first went dark, we managed to drive the Wailer back, trap it at the Tower. Many of our people died in the process.
Well, let’s not go there then. (BEAT) Doctor? (BEAT) Oh, terrific: we’re going to have to, aren’t we?
I’m afraid so.
Well then, let’s see if we can’t get a map on this thing. Budge up, Doctor.
FX: TONES AND BLEEPS AS MEL OPERATES SCREEN
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 32
SCENE 17: INT. CORRIDOR 3
(FX: CORRIDOR 3 IS ANOTHER NARROW ONE BUT VERY LONG WITH
THINK OF THE TWISTING ROUTE YOU GO
AIRCRAFT TO BAGGAGE RECLAIM, WITH SOME UP-AND-DOWN
TOO. ROGERS AND GALPAN RUNNING THROUGH )
This way, Rogers! There’s a cut-through to the Business Lounge those Economy types won’t know [about —]
FX: IN THE FAR DISTANCE, THE ECHOING SCREECH OF THE WAILER.
(STOPPING) What was that?
(STOPPING) Nothing. Keep going.
It was the Wailer, wasn’t it? It’s on the move!
Then we’d best not stand here waiting for it to find us. Come
on!
FX: THEY RUN ON. WAILER CRY CONTINUES INTO:
SPACEPORT FEAR by William Gallagher (FINAL) Page 33
SCENE 18: INT. ARRIVALS
(FX: THE SAME WAILER CRY, DISTORTED THROUGH ONE MORE WALL,
I’m almost afraid to say it, but that sounded rather like a wail.
